title.justification: This is the title provided at the beginning of the paper.

extractions.description: This research paper focuses on Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) applied to scenarios with stochastic reward functions. The paper introduces a new learning algorithm called quantile matching (QM) for GFlowNets that enables risk-sensitive policy generation by parameterizing edge flows through their quantile functions.

type.justification: The paper presents an improved algorithm and evaluates it experimentally against several benchmarks, demonstrating its efficacy through empirical results.
type.quote: In this work, we propose adopting a probabilistic approach to model the flow function... We also evaluate its performance on deterministic structured generation benchmarks.

name.justification: The paper focuses on probabilistic models and introduces a new approach for modeling the flow of probabilistic samplers under stochastic rewards.
name.quote: Generative Flow Networks (GFlowNets) are a family of probabilistic models to generate composite objects with a sequence of decision-making steps.

name.justification: The paper draws inspiration from reinforcement learning (RL) and aims for risk-sensitive policy generation in environments with both deterministic and stochastic rewards.
name.quote: Taking inspiration from RL, a GFlowNet policy takes a series of decision-making steps...

name.justification: GFlowNets are generative models used to sample diverse candidate solutions proportionally to a given reward function.
name.quote: GFlowNets are a family of probabilistic models to generate composite objects with a sequence of decision-making steps.

name.justification: The paper introduces the Quantile Matching (QM) GFlowNet as a new model for stochastic environments.
name.quote: We propose quantile matching (QM), a novel distributional GFlowNet training algorithm, for handling stochastic reward settings.

is_contributed.justification: The Quantile Matching (QM) GFlowNet was introduced in this paper.
is_contributed.quote: We propose quantile matching (QM), a novel distributional GFlowNet training algorithm, for handling stochastic reward settings.

is_executed.justification: The paper executes the QM GFlowNet model as part of their empirical evaluations on various benchmarks.
is_executed.quote: The proposed method also provides a stronger learning signal during training, which additionally allows it to outperform existing GFlowNet training approaches on standard benchmarks.

is_compared.justification: The paper compares the QM GFlowNet model with existing approaches such as Flow Matching and Trajectory Balance.
is_compared.quote: We also evaluate its performance on deterministic structured generation benchmarks. Our code is openly available at https://github.com/zdhNarsil/Distributional-GFlowNets.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper contains earlier works related to the Flow Matching algorithm, on which this paper builds upon.
referenced_paper_title.quote: To approximately satisfy the flow-matching constraint (Equation 4), the parameter θ can be trained to minimize the following flow matching (FM) objective for all intermediate states s′ ...

name.justification: The Hypergrid dataset is used for evaluating the performance of the QM GFlowNet in a structured combinatorial space.
name.quote: We investigate the hypergrid task from Bengio et al. (2021a). The space of states is a D-dimensional hypergrid cube with size H × · · · × H with H being the size of the grid.

referenced_paper_title.justification: This referenced paper proposed a version of the hypergrid task which serves as a benchmark for evaluating the performance of GFlowNets.
referenced_paper_title.quote: We investigate the hypergrid task from Bengio et al. (2021a)...

name.justification: The PyTorch library is used for implementing the models and running the experiments.
name.quote: thanks to the efficient implementation of batch network inference in PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019).

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper details the PyTorch library, which was used for the implementation and experimentation in this research.
referenced_paper_title.quote: thanks to the efficient implementation of batch network inference in PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019).
